title: Enhancing Language Multi-Agent Learning with Multi-Agent Credit Re-Assignment for Interactive Environment Generalization
author: Zhitao He (Institute for AI Industry Research, Tsinghua University), Zijun Liu (Department of Computer Science and Technology, Tsinghua University), Peng Li (Institute for AI Industry Research, Tsinghua University), May Fung (Hong Kong University of Science and Technology), Ming Yan (Alibaba Group), Ji Zhang (Alibaba Group), Fei Huang (Alibaba Group), Yang Liu (Institute for AI Industry Research, Tsinghua University)
relevance_why: The paper proposes a multi-agent learning framework that employs credit re-assignment to enhance generalizability across environments, potentially applicable to audio processing tasks where collaborative learning can benefit from varying input types.
background: This research focuses on developing a collaborative framework for multi-agent systems that improves performance and generalization across different interactive environments, such as web browsing and mobile operations.
contribution: This paper introduces CollabUIAgents to solve the challenges in multi-agent learning, achieving significant performance improvements and cross-environment generalization.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily rely on predefined roles and sparse outcome rewards that limit adaptability.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by utilizing a novel credit re-assignment strategy that leverages knowledge embedded in large language models to generate process rewards, enabling more robust training.

key_innovation: Combines multi-agent reinforcement learning with a credit re-assignment strategy that is grounded in large language models, enhancing both collaboration and learning efficiency.
real_world_impact: The framework has the potential to improve the efficiency of task automation in various applications by enabling agents to adapt quickly to new environments without extensive retraining.
limitations: The paper mentions that its framework is constrained by the number of agents and that the current voting mechanism may limit decision diversity.

new_terms.credit re-assignment: **Credit re-assignment** refers to a strategy in reinforcement learning where rewards are distributed based on process outcomes rather than final outcomes, promoting more effective learning signals across agents.

open_sourcing: The data and code are available at https://github.com/THUNLP-MT/CollabUIAgents
